data.title: All 44 Nancy Allen Movies (in Order)
data.meta_description: Get ready for a rollercoaster ride of emotions as we delve into the captivating world of Nancy Allen Movies. From heart-warming dramas to thrilling action films, this roundup article will take you onâ€¦

Get ready for a rollercoaster ride of emotions as we delve into the captivating world of Nancy Allen Movies. From heart-warming dramas to thrilling action films, this roundup article will take you on a journey through some of the most iconic movies featuring this talented actress. Prepare to be engaged and entertained as we explore her impressive filmography.

As an Amazonâ„¢ Associate, we earn from qualifying purchases.

1. The Last Detail (1973)

The Last Detailâ€ is a 1973 American comedy-drama film that showcases strong male bonding and captivating road trips through the U. S. Navy. Directed by Hal Ashby and written by Robert Towne, Darryl Ponicsan, this compelling movie has an impressive 7.5 IMDb rating with over 27,000 votes.

2. Carrie (1976)

Experience the chilling tale of Carrie (1976), a haunting horror movie directed by Brian De Palma. Based on Stephen Kingâ€™s novel, this terrifying film follows the life of Carrie White, a shy, sheltered teenager with a mysterious power â€” telekinesis.

3. The Last Victim (1976)

The Last Victim, â€œ a bone-chilling thriller from 1976, follows the terrifying exploits of a sadistic serial rapist as he relentlessly hunts down and murders prostitutes. As the body count rises and fear stalks the city, the victimsâ€™ families seek their own dark justice against the brutal killer. Director Jim Sotos, using the backdrop of a gritty 70s Los Angeles, crafts an eerie atmosphere that amplifies the storyâ€™s terror.

4. I Wanna Hold Your Hand (1978)

I Wanna Hold Your Handâ€ is a delightful and heartwarming movie set in the 1960s that tells the story of six teenagers from New Jersey. Fans of The Beatles embark on a hilarious and emotional journey, driving all the way to New York City in hopes of seeing their favorite band perform on The Ed Sullivan Show (1948). However, these enthusiastic youths donâ€™t have tickets to the event.

5. 1941 (1979)

1941" is an action-packed, hilarious comedy about the paranoia that gripped Californians as they braced for a Japanese invasion. Following the devastating attack on Pearl Harbor, the film showcases the antics that take place as people prepare to fend off the enemy. Directed by the legendary Steven Spielberg and co-starring John Belushi and Dan Aykroyd, â€œ1941â€ is a classic that stands out due to its unique mix of humor, action, and drama.

Home Movies, released in 1980, is a light-hearted comedy film that follows the quirky and creative life of Keith Gordon, a young man who has a passion for filmmaking. The story revolves around his unique family dynamics and the oddball antics of his peers, all under the watchful eye of â€œThe Maestro, â€œ who offers guidance and tips on his filmmaking techniques. This film is not just about the young man making a film but also showcases the power of creativity and the importance of preserving personal memories.

In the gripping mystery thriller â€œBlow Outâ€ (1981), John Travolta takes on the role of Jack Terry, a movie sound recordist who by accident records evidence of a car accident that turns out to be a murder. Strange Invadersâ€ is a sci-fi horror film released in 1983, set against the backdrop of a small town with a dark secret. Alien beings have taken residence in this seemingly ordinary community, but things take a deadly turn when a young professor attempts to save his daughter from their clutches. As the professor delves deeper into the alien invasion, he uncovers a shocking truth about the townâ€™s history and the beings that inhabit it.

In the gripping 1984 adventure film â€œThe Philadelphia Experiment, â€œ an unsuspecting crew on a United States Navy destroyer escort finds themselves caught in the middle of a dangerous experiment that has unforeseen consequences. The film, directed by Paul Bartel, stars Nancy Allen and Don Peoples as a tabloid reporter and her new photographer, respectively. The Buddy System, released in 1984, is a humorous romantic drama starring Richard Dreyfuss, Susan Sarandon, and Nancy Allen. Set in a quiet school, truant officer Joe becomes involved in a love triangle between his on-again, off-again girlfriend and the boyâ€™s mother. Limit Up is a 1989 fantasy-comedy film that follows the career-driven lifestyle of young trader Casey Falls. When faced with the opportunity to make it big by using her newfound supernatural abilities, Casey hesitantly accepts. But, as promised, Nike demands a high price â€” her very soul.

In the thrilling final installment of the RoboCop trilogy, RoboCop once again fights for justice in a world plagued by greed and corruption. This time, the half man/half robot hero is up against ruthless developers seeking to evict innocent people from their land in Old Detroit. With the help of his partner Officer Anne Lewis, RoboCop must make a difficult choice, deciding whether to stand for the people of Detroit or side with the powerful corporation, Omni Consumer Products.

Acting on Impulse is a whirlwind of comedy, mystery, and thrills that will keep you on the edge of your seat. The film, released in 1993, has a runtime of 1 hour and 33 minutes and is rated R. The Patriots, â€œ a thrilling 1994 drama directed by Eric Rochant, follows the life of 18-year-old Ariel Brenner as he leaves Paris and his family to live in Israel. Take a nostalgic journey back to the iconic decade of the â€™80s with â€œGreatest Ever 80s Moviesâ€! . 38. Bound by Flesh (2012)

Bound by Flesh is a captivating documentary that sheds light on the extraordinary lives of Daisy and Violet Hilton, the famous conjoined twins. From their humble beginnings as freak show attractions to their rise as stars of Vaudeville and films, the sisters defied societal expectations and paved the way for their own success. This inspiring and heartfelt film showcases the resilience and spirit of Daisy and Violet, as they faced the challenges of their unique circumstances and left a lasting mark on history.

40. De Palma (2015)

Experience an in-depth exploration of the legendary filmmaker Brian De Palma in the gripping documentary, â€œDe Palma. â€œ The film takes viewers on a riveting journey through the illustrious career of the mastermind behind critically acclaimed films like â€œObsession, â€œ â€œBody Double, â€œ â€œDressed to Kill, â€œ and â€œBlow Out. â€œ From his creative process to the challenges faced both on and off set, this compelling documentary invites you to delve into the world of De Palma. 41. Close Encounters with Vilmos Zsigmond (2016)

Close Encounters with Vilmos Zsigmond is a fascinating and heartwarming documentary that delves into the life and artistry of one of the most influential figures in contemporary cinematography, the Hungarian-born neorealist Vilmos Zsigmond. As one of the founding fathers of this craft, Zsigmond has left an indelible mark on the world of film, having worked with some of the biggest names in Hollywood. Through intimate interviews and behind-the-scenes footage, this documentary provides a rare glimpse into the life and work of a true master.

In Search of Darkness: Part II continues the riveting exploration of the â€™80s horror film era, delving deeper into the practical-effects decade and showcasing interviews with genre icons and industry experts.
